questions.question: Match the following: 1) Food adulteration a) Claviceps in wheat 2) Food additivity toxication d) Iodine in salt
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a Explanation: Food adulteration Vanaspati in ghee Food additivity Saccharin in health drinks Food fortification Iodine in salt Food toxication Claviceps in wheat Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 772, 773

questions.question: A patient presents with short, jerky steps, which developed progressively over the past month. He has been consuming Khesari dal for the past 8 months. Which of the following should be prescribed as prophylaxis to this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Vitamin C Explanation: The above scenario with a history of consuming khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) suggests neurolathyrism and vitamin C/ascorbic acid are used as prophylaxis. Lathyrism: Causative agent Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) present in Lathyrus sativus Significant exposure : >30% inclusion in diet over 2-6 months Clinical features Latent stage: preventive can be best implemented here No stick stage: most common point of diagnosis One-stick stage: muscular stiffness begins Two-stick stage: will need crutches Crawler stage: muscular atrophy sets in. Treatment Vitamin C prophylaxis: 500-1000 mg per day Banning the crop Toxin removal Steeping method: soaking in hot water for 2 hours, drained and sun-dried. Parboiling: overnight soaking in limewater. Genetic approach: selecting variants with less BOAA content and cultivating the same. Educating people. Bringing socio-economic changes.

questions.question: A patient presents with new onset swelling in both her legs associated with frequent diarrhoeal episodes and progressive breathlessness. She has a history of consumption of mustard oil. Which of the following adulterants would have caused the above presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Argemone oil Explanation: The above clinical scenario, with a history of mustard oil consumption, suggests epidemic dropsy , commonly occurring when mustard oil is contaminated with argemone oil. Epidemic dropsy: Clinical features Bilateral leg swelling, diarrhoea, dyspnoea, features of glaucoma and heart failure even up to death. Causative agent Sanguinarine (toxic alkaloid present in argemone oil). Detection of contamination Nitric oxide test: the presence of a red-brown ring when added to the sample oil indicates the presence of argemone oil. Paper chromatography test Prevention Accidental contamination: removing argemone weeds growing among oilseed crops. Deliberate contamination: enforcing Prevention of Food Adulteration Act.

questions.question: Which of the following toxins is responsible for endemic ascites?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Pyrrolizidines Explanation: Pyrrolizidine alkaloids are responsible for endemic ascites. Endemic ascites: Clinical features Features of hepatic damage: hepatomegaly, jaundice, ascites. Causative agent Panicum miliare (millet) contamination with crotalaria which contains the hepatotoxic pyrrolizidine alkaloids. Prevention Educating people Proper de-weeding Sieving: crotalaria seeds are smaller than millet seeds Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 772

questions.question: Which of the following is true about aflatoxicosis?

options.A: The G1 variant is not associated with hepatocellular carcinoma
options.B: The B1 variant can commonly be associated with infantile cirrhosis
options.C: The minimum temperature that favours toxin formation is 18 degrees C
options.D: Keeping moisture content <22% is recommended for prevention

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) The B1 variant can commonly be associated with infantile cirrhosis Explanation: The B1 variant of aflatoxins can be responsible for the occurrence of infantile cirrhosis, as evidenced by the detection of the same in breast milk and also in the urine of the affected infants Aflatoxicosis: Clinical features Features of hepatotoxicity (jaundice, hepatomegaly) Hepatocellular carcinoma Causative agent Infestation of Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus over stored rice, wheat, and corn Produce mycotoxins: aflatoxin B1 & G1 (both are hepatotoxic & carcinogenic) - (Option A) Risk factors Storage temperature of 11 to 37 degree Celsius (Option C) Moisture content >16% Prevention Educating people Moisture content <10% during storage (Option D) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 771,772

questions.question: What are the acute symptoms associated with ergotism caused by consuming ergot-infested grains?

options.B: Nausea, repeated vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Nausea, repeated vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness Explanation: The acute symptoms of Ergotism include nausea, repeated vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness lasting up to 24 to 48 hours. Ergotism: Ergot is a fungus (Claviceps purpurea) that infects food grains such as bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat during their flowering stages. Consumption of ergot-infested grains can lead to ergotism , characterised by acute symptoms such as nausea, repeated vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness lasting up to 24 to 48 hours. In chronic cases, ergotism may cause painful cramps in limbs and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. Modern high-yielding varieties of bajra are more susceptible to ergot infestation. Infested grains can be removed in 20% salt water, hand-picking, or air floatation. The upper safe limit for ergot alkaloids in food material is 0.05 mg per 100 grams. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 772

questions.question: What is the device shown in the image , used for?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Nutritional assessment Explanation: An image of Shakir’s tape is given [Mid Upper Arm Circumference-MUAC- Tape], used for nutritional assessment (malnutrition). Shakir’s tape: MUAC tapes measure the upper arm circumference of children and pregnant women to identify malnutrition. There are different types of MUAC tapes, all graduated in millimetres. Some tapes are colour-coded (red, yellow, green) to indicate nutritional status. MUAC tapes are used to assess nutritional status quickly and non-invasively, aiding in timely intervention for malnutrition. MUAC tapes for children and adults are available through UNICEF Supply Division warehouses. It cannot be used for infants. Interpretation: Red <11.5 cm Severe Malnutrition Yellow 11.5-12.5 cm Borderline Malnutrition Green >12.5 cm Normal

questions.question: What is one of the criteria used to define severe acute malnutrition (SAM) according to WHO standards?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Presence of nutritional oedema Explanation: Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) can be defined by: Very low weight-for-height/length (Z-score below -3SD). A mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm. The presence of nutritional oedema. SAM significantly increases the risk of death in children under five years of age. It can indirectly cause child death by increasing the case fatality rate in children suffering from common illnesses such as diarrhoea and pneumonia. Children who are severely wasted (SAM) are 9 times more likely to die than well-nourished children. MUAC >115 mm (Option A): SAM is defined by MUAC <115 mm , not above. Weight-for-age Z-score below -1 SD (Option B): This is not used for SAM diagnosis. Weight-for-age < -2 SD defines underweight , not SAM. Height-for-age Z-score below -2 SD (Option D): This defines stunting , a sign of chronic malnutrition, not acute malnutrition . Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 755

questions.question: Which of the following can be best used to determine acute malnutrition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Weight for height Explanation: Low weight for age Underweight Both chronic & acute malnutrition. Low height for age Stunting Chronic malnutrition Low weight for height Wasting Acute malnutrition Underweight: Used to assess changes in malnutrition over time; reflects both chronic & acute malnutrition. It is commonly used as a population health indicator since weight is easy to measure. Weight-for-age Z-score at least 2SD below the WHO Child Growth Standards median. Stunting: Reflects growth retardation due to a chronic aetiology (chronic inadequate nutrition or recurrent infections). Usually, it causes delayed psycho-social and cognitive development and poor school performance. Height-for-age Z-score at least 2SD below the WHO Child Growth Standards median. Wasting: Recent failure to receive adequate nutrition results in weight loss or failure to gain weight. Indicates acute malnutrition affected by recent illnesses like diarrhoea and acute food shortages. Rapid changes in individuals and populations are influenced by seasonal food availability and disease prevalence. Weight-for-height Z-score at least -2 SD below the median of WHO Child Growth Standards. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pages 754-755

questions.question: Which of the following is an age-independent anthropometric measure of malnutrition?

options.C: Weight for height and mid-upper arm circumference

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Weight for height and mid-upper arm circumference Explanation: To check the nutritional status, anthropometric indices are commonly used. The most common ones are: Weight for age. Height for age (chronic malnutrition). Weight for height (acute malnutrition). Mid-upper arm circumference . Age-independent indices: Weight for height. Mid-upper arm circumference . Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pages 754-755

questions.question: A 14-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns about poor growth. The child appears emaciated, with visible rib bones and a sunken appearance of face. On examination, there is minimal subcutaneous fat and muscle wasting. The mother reports that the infant has been exclusively breastfed, but she herself has been malnourished due to economic constraints. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Marasmus Explanation: The most likely diagnosis for the 14-month-old infant who appears emaciated with minimal subcutaneous fat and muscle wasting, especially in the context of being exclusively breastfed by a malnourished mother, is marasmus. Marasmus is a form of severe malnutrition characterised by energy deficiency. It typically presents with significant weight loss, visible rib bones, a sunken facial appearance, and muscle wasting. Protein-energy malnutrition: Kwashiorkor. Marasmus. Characteristic Kwashiorkor Marasmus Cause Low protein/energy ratio in diet Inadequate intake of both protein and energy Affected age group 1 to 4 years < 1 year Severity Severe Less severe Physical appearance Lethargic, moon face due to edema, flaky paint dermatosis & flag sign Alert & thin, loose wrinkled skin, baggy pants appearance & muscle wasting Feeding behaviour Children are usually voracious feeders. Often poor appetite or anorexia Oedema Present Minimal or no oedema Subcutaneous fat - Minimal or absent Muscle wasting Present Present Serum albumin levels Hypoalbuminemia (low albumin levels) Non-normal serum albumin levels Liver involvement Enlargement - Skin and hair changes Depigmentation - Other features Steatosis (fatty liver) -
